In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here's the function definition:

```julia
function wrap_string(input_str::String, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(input_str)
    result = IOBuffer()
    col = 0
    for word in words
        if col + length(word) > text_width
            print(result, '\n')
            col = 0
        else
            if !isempty(words) && col != 0
                print(result, ' ')
                col += 1
            end
        end
        print(result, word)
        col += length(word)
    end
    String(take!(result))
end
```

This function uses an IOBuffer to build the wrapped string. The variable `col` keeps track of how many characters are in the current line. It iterates over each word in the input string, and if adding the new word would exceed `text_width`, it starts a new line instead. Otherwise, it adds a space (if necessary) and then the word itself.

Here's an example:

```julia
input_str = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit."
println(wrap_string(input_str))
```

This will print:

```
Lorem
ipsum
dolor
sit
amet,
consectetur
adipiscing
elit.
```
